messages.messageBody:
> I hear so often that unschooling makes kids so "
> different " from
> other kids.

And is "different" suppose to be bad? I think it is a
compliment. And school is definately a tough place
for kids who (or kid's whose parents) refuse to abide
by the norm.

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] alternative /communism
messages.msgSnippet: On Tue, 11 Sep 2001 22:03:56 -0500 Julie Stauffer  ... Julie, Here in conservative, rural MT,  liberal, tree hugger, vegan is synonymous
messages.messageBody:
On Tue, 11 Sep 2001 22:03:56 -0500 "Julie Stauffer" <jnjstau@...>
writes:
> I am heterosexual and believe in a closed marriage, but I'm a
> communist...... and living in Texas that is pretty alternative.
> Julie

Julie,
Here in conservative, rural MT, liberal, tree hugger, vegan is
synonymous with communist! Add unschooling and WOW! ( never mind
religion! )
I lived on a commune for a few months in my younger days. A most
profound experience.

I hear so often that unschooling makes kids so " different " from
other kids. I'm thinking these kids being different already ( from
families that don't fit the norm ) is just one more reason to unschool.
Knowing some of the problems faced at the public school by some of my
friends children ( who are mainstream ) I shudder to think of what my
little guy might have faced.

How is unschooling working out for a communist in Texas?
Deb L
